title: Betty Harvie Anderson, Baroness Skrimshire of Quarter
text:
Margaret Betty Harvie Anderson, Baroness Skrimshire of Quarter, (12 August 1913 – 7 November 1979) was a British <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28UK%29">Conservative Party</a> politician. She was the first woman to become a <a href="Deputy%20Speaker%20of%20the%20House%20of%20Commons">Deputy Speaker of the House of Commons</a>, which she served as from 1970 to 1973.
Early life.
Harvie Anderson was born in <a href="Glasgow">Glasgow</a> on 12 August 1913 to Thomas Alexander Harvie Anderson and his wife Nessie Harvie Anderson (née Shearer). She was educated at <a href="St%20Leonards%20School">St Leonards School</a>, an <a href="Independent%20school%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">independent school</a> in <a href="St%20Andrews">St Andrews</a>.
Military service.
In 1938, she joined the <a href="Auxiliary%20Territorial%20Service">Auxiliary Territorial Service</a> (ATS). She was commissioned into the ATS as a company commander (equivalent in rank to <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a>) on 21 December 1938. When the ATS reorganised and granted full military status in 1941, she was made a second subaltern (equivalent in rank to a <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a>) on 30 May. She saw active service on the <a href="Home%20front%20during%20World%20War%20II">Home Front</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, including a posting to the <a href="River%20Forth">River Forth</a> during the German air raids. From 1942 to 1943, she was senior commander (equivalent in rank to <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a>) of a Mixed Heavy Anti-aircraft Regiment. She was ultimately appointed chief commander (equivalent in rank to <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">lieutenant colonel</a>) of a <a href="Anti-Aircraft%20Command">mixed anti-aircraft brigade</a>. She held the post until she left the ATS in 1946.
Political career.
In November 1945, Harvie Anderson was elected to <a href="Stirlingshire">Stirlingshire</a> <a href="County%20Council">County Council</a>. In 1953, she became leader of the <a href="Conservative%20Party%20%28UK%29">Moderate Group</a>.
Harvie Anderson stood for parliament for <a href="West%20Stirlingshire%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">West Stirlingshire</a> in 1950 and 1951 and in <a href="Sowerby%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Sowerby</a> in 1955. She was appointed an <a href="Officer%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">Officer of the Order of the British Empire</a> (OBE) in 1956.
She was <a href="Member%20of%20Parliament%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Member of Parliament</a> (MP) for <a href="Renfrewshire%20East%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Renfrewshire East</a> from 1959 to 1979. Although <a href="Betty%20Boothroyd">Betty Boothroyd</a> was the first female <a href="Speaker%20of%20the%20House%20of%20Commons%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">Speaker of the House of Commons</a>, Harvie Anderson was the first woman to sit in the Speaker's Chair as a <a href="Deputy%20Speaker">Deputy Speaker</a> (Deputy Chairman of Ways and Means) from 1970 to 1973. In the 1970s Harvie Anderson helped turn Conservative Party policy against <a href="History%20of%20Scottish%20devolution">Scottish Devolution</a> which she regarded as a threat to the future of the United Kingdom. She retired as an MP in 1979.
Harvie Anderson was given a <a href="life%20peerage">life peerage</a> in the <a href="1979%20Birthday%20Honours">1979 Birthday Honours</a>. She took the unusual title of Baroness Skrimshire of Quarter, of <a href="Dunipace">Dunipace</a> in the District of <a href="Falkirk">Falkirk</a>, made up of her husband's surname and the estate she owned in Scotland.
On 7 November 1979, within a week of her introduction to the <a href="House%20of%20Lords">House of Lords</a>, she died suddenly having suffered an <a href="asthma">asthma</a> attack.
Personal life.
On 5 May 1960, Harvie Anderson married John Francis Penrose Skrimshire, a medical doctor and heart specialist. They had no children.
